awd_titl_txt: Environmental regulation of spinal cord development
awd_abstract_narration:
During development, the cells that form the brain need to produce many different kinds of neurons in order to generate the complicated neural circuits found in adults, a process called differentiation. Many different molecules affect the patterning of the embryonic nervous system; these molecules have been used to identify biochemical pathways that are part of the developmental programs cells utilize to acquire their individual neuronal identities. However, the extent to which the environment intervenes in the functioning of this developmental program, is an understudied aspect of neural development. This research project documents ways in which nervous system development is dynamic and sensitive to the environment in which it occurs, challenging the idea of a predetermined, rigid genetic program that completely dictates the fate of neural cells before they are born. A mechanistic explanation for the observed plastic changes (that the environmental plasticity produces neural circuits that better match an individual's performance to the particular environment they develop in) is also tested. The research will assess the influence of temperature on neuronal differentiation in the embryonic frog spinal cord, and chart the mechanisms through which temperature differences change the sensorimotor behavior of developing tadpoles. Understanding these basic mechanisms of nervous system development will benefit society by contributing to knowledge about neurodevelopmental disorders and spinal cord regeneration. In addition, this project will establish an educational program at the K-12 school in Shriners Hospital for Children Northern California. Children are patients, mostly from low-income families; they will be offered a school program when they need to stay long-term at the Hospital, a non-profit organization that cares for the children at no cost. The project will expose these children to hands-on science activities and the scientific method. 

This investigation hypothesizes that environmental cues modulate embryonic calcium activity in developing neurons, thus regulating spinal neuron differentiation and the establishment of effective locomotor circuitry. Using a multidisciplinary approach, this study will identify the mechanisms by which environmental temperature modulates calcium-mediated spontaneous electrical activity resulting in specification of developing spinal neurons. The study hypothesizes that the cold-sensitive transient receptor potential cation channel M8 (TRPM8) contributes to the higher frequency calcium spike activity observed at cold temperatures. Pharmacological and genetic approaches will be implemented to assess the necessity and sufficiency of TRPM8 in cold temperature-induced changes in calcium activity. Differentiation and patterns of connectivity of sensory and motor neuron populations in animals grown at different temperatures after reaching identical tadpole stages will be examined by immunostaining and luciferase assay reporters. This investigation will determine the mechanisms underlying the changes in sensory and motor neuron differentiation by rescuing the temperature-driven phenotype through imposing counteracting approaches to the changes in calcium spike activity. To determine the consequences of the temperature-driven changes in neuronal differentiation on sensorimotor behavior and to test whether there is interaction between the temperature at which animals are grown and the sensorimotor performance, embryos will be raised at different temperatures until tadpole stages when the flexion reflex and the swimming pattern will be assessed at different temperatures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During vertebrate development, spinal cord neurons acquire specialized identities to establish a network for executing sensorimotor functions. Spontaneous electrical activity regulates different aspects of the birth and differentiation of spinal cord neurons. Whether environmental cues modulate electrical activity in developing spinal cord neurons and in turn influence their specialization and survival has remained unclear. The discoveries from this investigation show that growing frog embryos at cold temperature results in swimming larvae with higher number of spinal cord motor neurons compared to larvae raised in warm temperature. This change in spinal cord development optimizes the escape response to gentle touch of animals grown and tested at cold temperatures. A cold-sensitive ion channel increases calcium spike frequency of developing ventral spinal cord neurons, which in turn regulates expression of motor neuron differentiation proteins. The cold-sensitive ion channel is necessary for both the increase in motor neuron number of animals grown in cold temperatures and for their enhanced sensorimotor behavior when tested at cold temperatures. These findings suggest the environment modulates neuronal differentiation to optimize the behavioral outcome of the developing organism. Given that fetuses and preterm neonates lack mature thermoregulation, our findings suggest aberrant fluctuations in fetal or neonatal body temperature may impact neurodevelopment.

At the core of this study is the concept that brain and spinal cord development do not result from a mere execution of a hardwired genetic program in which a master switch is turned on early in embryonic development and follows instructions blindly until the nervous system matures. Instead, this study argues that the environment can modify the development and function of the nervous system to adapt it for an optimized functional outcome. It also emphasizes that sudden and pathological changes in the environment may affect neurodevelopment.

This investigation also demonstrates that expression of environment-sensitive ion channels during development may serve as a mechanism through which the environment influences gene expression. This addresses a major question in developmental biology of how the environment can impact gene expression. 

In mammals, warm and hot temperature-sensitive channels are likewise expressed early in development. Considering that thermoregulation is established over the first months of postnatal life in humans or even longer in premature babies, the effect of changes in environmental temperature to nervous system development becomes a health concern. Indeed, alterations in temperature in mammals, including humans, correlate with varied consequences to neurodevelopment. For instance, the incidence of schizophrenia, considered a neurodevelopmental disorder in origin, associates with birth seasonality, which in turn correlates with winter diseases during pregnancy. Although infections lead to complex reactions, one parameter that has been considered as a potential factor influencing offspring?s neurodevelopmental outcome is fever during pregnancy. The risk of autism spectrum disorder in children born to mothers who experienced febrile episode during pregnancy is increased, according to several epidemiological studies, and diminished by antipyretic medications. Because expression of temperature-sensitive ion channels is not restricted to adult sensory neurons, changes in temperature will have an impact on neural activity during nervous system development as shown in this study.

We suggest that physiological and pathological changes in temperature modify nervous system development in diverse species, including humans. When changes are long-term the system adapts to optimize responses in the new environment. However, when changes are sudden and occur during critical periods, or when the molecular mechanisms to adapt to these changes are not functional, temperature-dependent alterations in neuronal activity can be detrimental to neurodevelopmental outcomes.

In addition, this investigation examines the mechanisms regulating developmental cell death, characteristic of the developing nervous system. Neurons are produced in early stages of development in larger numbers than needed for achieving mature function. Through a process of competitive elimination and programmed cell death the ?excess? of generated neurons is pruned. Our discoveries argue that environmental factors participate in this mechanism, and we are currently investigating the molecular players responsible for regulating, in a temperature-dependent manner, the rate and magnitude of developmental spinal cord neuron cell death.

We have disseminated the findings from our research during the tenure of this award through 20 presentations in scientific meetings, 6 peer-reviewed publications and 3 PhD dissertation theses. Additionally, two publications have been submitted and posted as preprints and are under consideration for publication. In addition, we have been invited to present our research progress in several venues.

The awarded project has allowed the training and mentoring of three undergraduate students, four graduate students, a research associate, three postdoctoral fellows, and three project scientists. The PI has taught in Physiology courses and served as Course Director and Discipline Leader for Physiology in the School of Medicine new curriculum. 

This award facilitated implementing a summer youth program for high school students and developing a K-12 program for the pediatric patients at the Shriners Hospital for Children. We participated in the Ventricular Foundation visits to K-12 public schools.
